items.synopsis: The local share market is trading lower today, following Wall Street's losses. Qantas loses its High Court appeal over the sacking of 1,700 workers during the pandemic.Â Follow updates in our live blog.

title.children: Qantas issues first-ever apology to workers it illegally sacked during pandemic, ASX in the red led by tech stocks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Employment and Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke has welcomed the High Court decision against Qantas during question time in Parliament today. "We congratulate the workers and we congratulate the Transport Workers Union which took this case forward. Some of the 1,700 illegally sacked workers are here today in the public gallery right now. I say to the workers who were illegally sacked that you did nothing wrong. Qantas broke the law."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Workplace Relations Minister welcomes union's win against Qantas

children.content: The Employment and Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke has
Â
welcomed the High Court decision against Qantas during question time in Parliament today.
"We congratulate the workers and we congratulate the Transport Workers Union which took this case forward.
Some of the 1,700 illegally sacked workers are here today in the public gallery right now.
I say to the workers who were illegally sacked that you did nothing wrong.
Qantas broke the law."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chinese property developers entered the Australian market back in the 2000s with big ambitions. Country Garden, along with several top companies, invested billions of dollars buying â€” and developing â€” prime sites. Now, just a few years later, debt-laden developers are selling or downsizing their operations here in Australia, as China's property market worsens. If you missed it last night, you can watch the full story from business reporter Samuel Yang below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians are spending (slightly more) again, particularly on education, transport and recreation. The CommBank Household Spending Insights index rose 0.7% in August from July, which was flat. The index is based on 12 spending categories and uses payment data from about 7 million Commonwealth Bank customers (which comprises about 30% of Australian consumer transactions). An increase in the number of international students meant spending on education grew 2.8%, while the FIFA Women's World Cup and big-name concert tours pushed recreational spending up 1.9%. Higher petrol prices drove up spending on transport by about 2%. However, the annual rate of increases is significantly down from its peak of 18% last yea r. CBA chief economist Stephen Halmarick says annual spending growth remains subdued as households manage the increased cost of living. "The effects of the 400bp of Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate rises is clearly reflected in a significant slowdown in annual household spending growth measured by the CommBank HSI Index. "Monetary policy is now restrictive and financial conditions will continue to tighten in the months ahead on the lagged effect of RBA interest rate hikes and the fixed rate mortgage refinancing task. "We continue to expect household spending to weaken further over the remainder of 2023 and into 2024." Households spent less on hospitality and utilities (reflecting the government rebates available for energy bills).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending rebounds helped by FIFA Women's World Cup

children.content: Australians are spending (slightly more) again, particularly on education, transport and recreation.
Â
The CommBank Household Spending Insights
index rose 0.7%
in August from July, which was flat.
The index is based on 12 spending categories and uses payment data from about 7 million Commonwealth Bank customers (which comprises about 30% of Australian consumer transactions).
An increase in the number of international students meant spending on
education grew 2.8%
, while the FIFA Women's World Cup and big-name concert tours pushed
recreational spending up 1.9%
. Higher petrol prices drove up spending on
transport by about 2%
However, the
annual rate of increases is significantly down from its peak of 18% last yea
r.
CBA chief economist Stephen Halmarick says annual spending growth remains subdued as households manage the increased cost of living.
"The effects of the 400bp of Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate rises is clearly reflected in a significant slowdown in annual household spending growth measured by the CommBank HSI Index.
"Monetary policy is now restrictive and financial conditions will continue to tighten in the months ahead on the lagged effect of RBA interest rate hikes and the fixed rate mortgage refinancing task.
"We continue to expect household spending to weaken further over the remainder of 2023 and into 2024."
Households spent less on hospitality and utilities (reflecting the government rebates available for energy bills).
